content.intro_para: Teenage girls just want to hang out, be with their friends, carelessly hook up with boys and go to "" matches. Adults, always middling in their lives is just another obstacle to overcome to emerge as young, independent women. The teenage girls from Mustang, however, also have a different approach to marriage than their adoptive family is used to; they want to choose whom to marry. They want to have freedom to leave their village, the freedom to an education and the freedom to act their age. The story follows a trajectory that is reminiscing of other, feel-good, empowering women stories, however, the storytelling is what sets it apart. The female perspective is strong, very personal, and follows the girls from carefree fun to downfall. The trouble is heavily masked in the first ten minutes of the film, where carefree play with some boys at the beach, turns into a shameful interrogation and demonstration of abuse from the girls' uncle. The cascading withdrawal from society instigated by the claustrophobic imprisonment of the girls because of their innocent fun,is done wonderfully by the Turkish born French director Deniz Gamze Erg√ºven. The humor, sisterly warmth, friendship, and ridiculous ploys of rebellion add a warmth to a story very much about oppressive norms, and the coming of age story is much better for it.

body.p: Quite swiftly the caretakers of the girls, their grandmother and uncle, successfully remove all "corruptions" that may affect the girls even further. They begin by removing schools and with it boys, "revealing" clothing, and all digital media as well as games. The girls, understandably begin to reactively push away, by cutting thigh high slits into their brown, shapeless clothes, spitting in the coffee of their soon to be mothers in law, or even having sex with strange boys in their uncle's car. Lale, the youngest of the five sisters emerges as the wily, most ferocious of them all, quickly evoking feelings of sympathy and encouragement from the audience.
